vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == nominatedOwner, "You must be nominated before you can accept ownership");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == owner, "Only the contract owner may perform this action");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (TestableSelfDestructible.sol#40): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (TestableSelfDestructible.sol#112): it allows old versions

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 116)
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(initiationTime + SELFDESTRUCT_DELAY < now, "Self destruct delay not met");
vulnerability_findings.message:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.timestamp environment variable.
The block.timestamp environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
Classification: SWC-116

vulnerability_findings.name: Unprotected Selfdestruct (SWC 106)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Any sender can cause the contract to self-destruct.
Any sender can trigger execution of the SELFDESTRUCT instruction to destroy this contract account and withdraw its balance to an arbitrary address. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and make sure that appropriate security controls are in place to prevent unrestricted access.
Classification: SWC-106
